learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the drivers of sustainable practices in contemporary business and key concepts in sustainability including principles of governance, corporate legitimacy, stakeholder engagement and disclosure.

Demonstrate an understanding of key aspects of strategy, planning and reporting in sustainable business practice, including the Global Reporting Initiative, the CERES Roadmap, various relevant standards and certification schemes and how to apply the concept of Materiality.

Demonstrate an understanding of how to estimate, monitor and manage inputs and outputs like water, energy, waste and emissions from organisations, products and services, particularly in the built environment.
Demonstrate an understanding of principles of sustainable procurement, lean supply chain management and sustainable design.

Demonstrate an understanding of how human rights and social justice principles feature in sustainable business practice, particularly in regards to securing licenses to operate, effective employee management and ethical engagement with stakeholders, notably vulnerable groups and indigenous people.
Demonstrate an understanding of the influence of the banking, insurance and investment sector on sustainable business practice expectations and standards.

assessments.task_description:
Length: 1,500–1,800 words

Objective:Critically assess a real-world company’s ESG performance, with a focus on the comparative application of multiple frameworks (e.g., GRI vs. SASB vs. TCFD). Students must analyze materiality determination, climate and biodiversity disclosures, and implications for investor decision-making.

Output: Executive-level ESG brief + critical analysis appendix.

Assessment Criteria: Analytical depth, integration of frameworks, clarity, referencing, and professional tone.

Adaptation for External Students:

  1. Students may use examples from their own organization (if permissible).
  2. No live presentation required.
  3. Optional video summary to enhance engagement.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Title: Designing a Net-Zero and Inclusive ESG Transition Strategy

Format: 8–10 minute recorded video presentation using tools like Zoom, Teams, or Loom.

Objective: Develop a complete ESG strategy for a real or hypothetical organization transitioning toward net-zero emissions, DEI, and circular practices. Include scenario modeling, stakeholder mapping, risks, and opportunities aligned with material ESG metrics.

Assessment Criteria: Strategy innovation, realism, stakeholder inclusivity, data-driven insights, team collaboration, and professional delivery.

Adaptation for External Students:

  1. Online team formation via Blackboard.
  2. Collaboration through Microsoft Teams or shared platforms.
  3. Recorded presentations are reviewed asynchronously by staff.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Title: Evaluating ESG Governance and Reflecting on Systemic Change

Length: 2,000–2,200 words

Objective: Write a critical evaluation of an organization’s ESG governance structure, use of digital ESG tools, and alignment with frameworks like TNFD or CSRD. Reflect on the system-wide barriers and your evolving role as a change agent in business sustainability.

Output: Strategy critique (60%) + personal professional reflection (40%).

Assessment Criteria: Critical insight, integration of course theory, originality, personal learning synthesis, and communication quality.

Adaptation for External Students:

  1. Can use their employer (with anonymization if needed).
  2. Reflection can be written or audio-recorded for flexibility.
  3. Encourages integration with real-world work experience.
